data.title: Show Recently Opened Folders in Windows Task-Bar Jump-List
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows 10

When you pin VS Code to the Windows Task-Bar and right-click on the task-bar icon, the jump-list shows only "New Window" and doesn't list recently opened folders - it should! And they should be pinnable!

![2016-03-27 vs code jump list](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6370145/14066680/8a066588-f450-11e5-89ac-da7ee03660b0.png)

I really like the way that an opened folder replaces the full-fat Project concept of classic Visual Studio. By improving the Jump-List, things will be even better because working on multiple "projects" will become far more convenient.

data.title: Documentation for Keybinding Customisation should list `when' predicates
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Visit the documentation at https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/customization/keybindings
2. Observe the truly excellent coverage of 'key' and 'command' and other concepts, particularly the "Accepted Keys" and "Keyboard layouts" subheadings.
3. Observe that there is no table of predicates that may be used for `when' attributes - there is not even a note about the use of logical operators.

Inside VS Code, when the default keyboard shortcut definitions are open, you can discover a few of the predicates by reading existing definitions. For example, without scrolling down, I can see that `editorTextFocus`, `inReferenceSearchEditor` and `editorHasSelection` all exist and that they can be combined with the `&&` operator. The only one that is mentioned in the documentation is `editorTextFocus`.

data.title: Cannot use incremental search in Command Pallet.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  - 0.10.12-insider
  - Commit: ef2a1fcaa553d14d7731b284a5ac5e4a55c42936
  - Date: 2016-03-21T11:33:38.240Z
  - Shell: 0.35.6
  - Renderer: 45.0.2454.85
  - Node: 4.1.1
- OS Version:
  - Windows 7 64bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use Command Pallet in Japanese

![command-pallet-i18n](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1937871/14066294/c4e20786-f480-11e5-852c-4a46e97ff853.gif)

I cannot use commands in English.
Japanese IME inputs text as hiragana at first. Then we push the space key, then the text is converted to a combination of hiragana, katakana, and kanji.
This is meaning we cannot use incremental search efficiently.

This is very inconvenient.

Can I turn i18n off?

data.title: `getWordRangeAtPosition` result is neither a closed interval nor half-open
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  0.10.12-insider
- OS Version:
  Ubuntu 14.04

From my comment in aioutecism/amVim-for-VSCode#52

Some problems with `getWordRangeAtPosition`:
- it tries to return a half-open range (start is inclusive, end is not), but it's more like a quasi-half-open range
- most of the time when the cursor is positioned inside non-words, it returns undefined

The one exception to the latter point is that it _won't_ return undefined if called from a position at the end of one of those half-open ranges.  For example, for the string

```
foo bar  baz   fum
```
- inside "foo" it returns character offsets [0, 3)
- inside "foo" it returns [4, 7)
- inside "foo" it returns [9, 12)
- inside "foo" it returns [15, 18)

But:
- for the space before "fum" it returns undefined
- for the space before "baz" it returns undefined
- for the space before "bar" it returns [0, 3)

Even if someone says, "the word's range end should point to an offset just past the end of the word", then I would say, "great, that's called a half-open interval, but the space after 'foo' and 'bar' and 'baz' should still be consistent with the subsequent spaces, and right now it isn't, which means sometimes it's treating the range as a half-open interval, and other times it's treating it as a closed interval".

data.title: Visual studio code intellisense ignoring tsconfig.json file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.6
- OS Version: Ubuntu 15.10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add tsconfig.json with target: es6
2. try to use `Set` in your typescript source
3. compile file successfully with the tsc command
4. see that inteliisense in visual studio is ignoring your tsconfig.json file and reacting as if you just ran `tsc myfile.ts` (Cannot find name Set)

data.title: Command palette's camel case matching does not work for non ASCII characters
data.body:
From @espresso3389 in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4679:

> I'm on Windows 10 and the IME is ATOK; a Japanese thirdparty IME.
> Even with MS-IME, the behavior is same.
> Typing "git: プル" correctly works but doing "git プル" does not work.
> The search function does not seem to work with Japanese characters.

![eea0c49e-f3a0-11e5-9726-32dff53190f6](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/14063489/67b2e16e-f388-11e5-8539-ff5dbf2efb3a.gif)

Is there an optimization to not recheck characters if the last character is replaced? While not being shown here, Japanese IMEs can also transforms multiple Japanese characters into an even smaller number of characters, by going from English -> Kana -> Kanji.

data.title: Importing scoped npm modules without scope name
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.10
- OS Version: Ubuntu 15.10

This is a question.

We have some private NPM packages using npmjs' private repository. Assume
- scope name : `@scope`
- private package name as : `private-package`

When we install this NPM package using 
`npm install @scope/private-package` 

It is installed to : `./node_modules/@scope/private-package`

In VSCode, to import some thing from this package, we need to do
`import {SomeThing} from '@scope/private-package'`

Is there anything in TypeScript configuration or VSCode settings that we can re-map
`@scope/private-package` to `private-package` 
so that we can use like 
`import {SomeThing} from 'private-package'` instead of adding`@scope`?

data.title: No  comments styles applied for specific text
Menu action Toggle Render Whitespace is a no-op if editor does not have focus
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
I think related to #2110 possibly a regression
1. Open a project folder with cursor not in the editor
2. View -> Toggle Render Whitespace

Actual:
Toggle does not show whitespace dots until the cursor is placed in the editor window regardless of how many times you toggle.

Expected:
Cursor does not need to be in the editor to toggle whitespace

data.title: Getting error message "Failed to terminate running task" when trying to terminate the running task.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  launch app and open a folder which contains .less file.
2. Configure task runner from command palette and update task.json for below section:
"tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "install",
            "args": ["install","less"]
        },
3. Now save the updated file and press F1 and type : Run task
4. Select "Install" option from the list.
5. Verify you can see task running icon display in the status bar.
6. Now try to terminate the current running task. (Try to execute new task and it will show the pop-up to terminate running task. ).
7. Click on "Terminate Running task".
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14055818/32e56542-f2a2-11e5-87f8-cac54c12f9dd.png)

Actual:
1. Throwing error message like :  Failed to terminate running task
2. Output window it is displaying message like: 
The task 'install' was terminated per user request.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14055710/449fa55a-f2a1-11e5-900a-bca04289fcc2.png)

2. sudo ln -s /vscode/path/code-alpha /usr/local/bin/code-alpha

data.title: Programmatically update .tmLanguage scope match string
data.body:
Is there a way of doing that? Let's say I have an entry in my .tmLanguage:

``` xml
<dict>
    <key>match</key>
    <string>\b(MyFunction_First|MyFunction_Second|SpecialStuff)\b</string>
    <key>name</key>
    <string>keyword.SCARDOC.userfunction</string>
</dict>
```

And I'd like to populate that match with a list of function names I have ripped from workspace files.
I'm currently using `completionItemProvider` and `signatureHelpProvider` to auto-complete these user functions, and the final step would be to give them a distinguishable color (with my separate theme, that would just refer to `keyword.SCARDOC.userfunction`, of course).

data.body:

I'd like to be able to fold all the comments in a file with a shortcut, something like `editor.foldAllComments`.
This is probably linked to this issue : [folding] language-aware folding #3422

The idea, is to make it easier to transform a file like this :

data.title: TextDocument.setText
data.body:
There is a `TextDocument.getText()` method but there isn't a `TextDocument.setText()` method. The reason I (think) need this is for my [final-newline](https://github.com/SamVerschueren/vscode-final-newline) extension. It adds a final newline when the page is saved. But if the user presses `Save All` from the menus, it doesn't work because it only performs the action on the current active text editor document.

I listen to the `onDidSaveTextDocument`, which calls a listener with the `TextDocument` as parameter. From there on I can get the text, save the document, etc. but I cannot manipulate the document. Is this something that should be done differently?
